revision.comment: /* Use in media and popular culture */ trivia insignificant for plot
revision.text:
{{Other uses}} [[File:Wiener ZÃ¼nder.jpg|thumb|240px|[[Blasting machine]] used in mining ]] "'''Fire in the hole'''" is a warning that an [[Explosion|explosive detonation]] in a confined space is imminent. It originated with [[mining|miners]], who needed to warn their fellows that a [[explosive charge|charge]] had been set.{{cite web|title=Fire in the hole|url=http://www.word-detective.com/2008/10/fire-in-the-hole/|publisher=The Word Detective|date=October 10, 2008}} The phrase appears in this sense in state mining regulations,{{cite web|url=http://www.ilga.gov/commission/jcar/admincode/062/062002250000550R.html|title=Illinois Administrative Code 225.55}}{{cite web|url=http://adminrules.idaho.gov/rules/2011/17/0803.pdf|title=Idaho Administrative Code}} in military and corporate procedures,{{cite web|url=http://www.patrick.af.mil/news/story.asp?id=123409836|title=Here comes the boom}}{{cite web|url=https://www.nsf.gov/about/contracting/rfqs/support_ant/docs/mgt_manuals/mcm/blastingsop-499.pdf|title=Blasting Standard Operating Procedure, Raytheon Polar Services Company}} and in various mining and military blasting-related print books and narratives.{{cite web|url=https://www.google.com/search?tbm=bks&hl=en&q=%22fire+in+the+hole%22&gws_rd=ssl|title=Google Books}} [[NASA]] has used the term to describe a means of staging a [[multistage rocket]] vehicle by igniting the upper stage simultaneously with the ejection of the lower stage, without a usual delay of several seconds. On the [[Apollo 5]] unmanned flight test of the first [[Apollo Lunar Module]], a "fire in the hole test" used this procedure to simulate a lunar landing abort. [[Gene Kranz]] describes the test in his autobiography:
The fire-in-the-hole test involved shutting down the descent rocket, blowing the bolts that attached the ascent and descent stages, switching control and power to the ascent stage, and igniting the ascent rocket while still nestled to the landing stage.{{cite book|first=Gene|last=Kranz|authorlink=Gene Kranz|title=Failure is not an option|publisher=[[Berkley Books]]|date=2001|isbn=0425179877|page=215}}
== References == {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Fire in the hole}} [[Category:English phrases]] [[Category:Explosion protection]]
